CHAPTER 1

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1   INTRODUCTION and PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Thermo No. 1 BE-01, LLC ("Thermo No. 1"), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Cyrq Energy is a binary cycle geothermal power generation plant.  In the power generation process, iso-pentane is used as the binary working fluid.  Due to the chemical characteristics of iso-pentane and the quantities stored and used on site, it qualifies as a regulated substance under the provisions of Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions and the establishment of a Risk Management Plan or RMP.

The purpose of this RMP is to assist Thermo No. 1 with preventing or minimizing the consequences of accidental releases of vapors, flammable, or explosive substances that could cause harm to the surrounding public and/or the environment.  This RMP update qualifies as the required five (5) year update to the original RMP submitted in Jan. 2013.  

This RMP update has been developed by AAL Consulting, LLC on behalf of Thermo No. 1 to meet the requirements of 40 CFR 68, furthermore called the "Rule".  The format of this RMP update will also follow a similar format to the original submittal in 2013 for ease of employee and operator understanding and use. 

Process Description

Thermo No. 1 utilizes geothermal production wells to deliver heated well water to the vaporizer and then a pre-heater each of which are shell and tube type heat exchangers.  The heat exchangers utilize a binary system where the well water doesn't actually come in contact with a separately contained working fluid (iso-pentane).  Because iso-pentane's boiling point is much lower than water the fluid vaporizes quickly creating enough pressure to spin the turbines.  The spinning turbines are each coupled to opposite ends of the generator and electricity is produced.  The iso-pentane and the well water remain in their own separate closed loop systems.

The iso-pentane vapor then moves from the turbines into the conde

nsers.  Here the iso-pentane vapor is condensed back into a liquid as water from an adjacent cooling tower circulates through the condenser tubes, thus dropping the temperature and condensing the vapor.  Once the iso-pentane is back in a liquid form, it is pressurized using feed pumps and re-circulated through the heat exchangers and the whole closed loop process continues.

The facility currently generates approximately 12 MW gross of "green" electricity.

The entire iso-pentane closed loop system involving the heat exchangers, vaporizers and condensers along with the adjacent storage tank containing the iso-pentane will be considered as the "process" throughout this manual and update.

Iso-pentane is the regulated substance above the threshold quantity listed in the Rule, thus requiring the facility to register this chemical and follow the requirements of an RMP.


1.2   LOCATION AND SITE DESCRIPTION

Thermo No. 1 is situated in the remote desert region of Utah approximately 17 miles west of the town of Minersville and approximately 1.0 mile north of the Beaver County/Iron County line (see Figure 1.1 - Site & Facility Location Map).   The entire site consists of approximately 1,120 acres of land with the facility and production/injection wells occupying only 68 acres of the land.  The elevation of the power-generation facility is approximately 5,700 feet above sea level.  Topography at the site slopes gently to the northwest at a slope of approximately 50 vertical feet per mile.  Thermo Hot Springs are located approximately 1.0 mile northwest of the facility in the center of the valley between the Black and Shauntie Mountain ranges.

The actual facility with the power generation equipment, support equipment, offices and substation occupy approximately 8 acres on the site.  The entire facility area is fenced with the front main office as the security point of check in for all contractors, visitors and/or vendors.

1.3   APPLICABILITY

The working fluid used in the

Thermo No. 1 geothermal power generation process is iso-pentane (CAS No. 78-78-4).  The Safety Data Sheet listing all the chemical and physical properties for iso-pentane is found in Appendix A - (NEW) Conoco/Phillips SDS for Iso-pentane.   
In the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions Rule, certain toxic and/or flammable substances are regulated under the Rule.  These regulated substances and their threshold quantities are listed in Tables 1, 2, 3, and 4 of 40 CFR 68.130.  If a facility has a regulated substance greater than the listed threshold quantity contained in the process, then the substance and the facility must meet the requirements of the Rule.  Isopentane is found in Table 3, with a threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.

At the Thermo No. 1 site, exact quantities used in the process and their storage locations can be found in Table 1-1 - Iso-pentane Quantity and Storage Locations.
Table 1-1 - Iso-pentane Quantity and Storage Locations
Level 2
Heat Exchangers/Vaporizers/Condensers	16,500 gal.	   16,500 gal.

The total volume of iso-pentane in use and contained in the Level 2 process at the Thermo No. 1 site is 16,500 gallons or 85,372 lbs. @ a bulk density of 5.174 lbs./gal.  This volume and weight exceeds the 10,000 lb. threshold in the Level 2 process, therefore iso-pentane and the Thermo No. 1 facility is required to comply with the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions standard (40 CFR 68), and establish a Risk Management Plan or RMP.

Under the Rule, facilities are also required to determine their level of compliance and registration, dependent upon whether Program 1, 2, or 3 criterion is met (see 40 CFR 68.10(b)).  During the past five years (2013-2018) the Thermo No. 1 facility continues to meet the eligibility requirements of a Program 1 certification.  A facility is eligible for Program 1 certification provided it meets the following requirements:

For the five years prior to the submission of an RMP, and the five years since, the process has not

had an accidental release of the regulated substance (iso-pentane) where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any of the following offsite consequences:

(i) Death;
(ii) Injury; or
(iii) Response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor

This Plan is written to meet the requirements established in the Rule under Program 1 certification, and continues to certify that no additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases.

1.4 Site Process Safety Management (PSM)/Risk Management Program (RMP)

The site's PSM/RMP Program consists of fourteen (14 ) elements and these include:
(i)     Employee Participation
(ii)    Process Safety Information
(iii)   Process Hazard Analysis
(iv)   Operating Procedures
(v)    Training
(vi)   Contractors
(vii)  Pre-Start Up Review
(viii) Mechanical Integrity
(ix)   Hot Wok Permit
(x)    Management of Change
(xi)   Incident Investigation
(xii)  Emergency Planning and Response
(xiii) Compliance Audits
(xiv) Trade Secrets

Following is a description for each element:

1) Employee Participation

Thermo No. 1 has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation required by PSM.  Thermo No. 1 has consulted with employees, equipment design experts and other representatives during the development of process hazard analyses and on other elements of process management.  All information concerning the process hazard analysis (PHA) findings & recommendations and the entire PSM manual has been communicated to employees and made available to them for future review.

Employees are encouraged to participate in the PSM process according to:  EHS-SOP 9.0 Employee Participation Program (in PSM Manual).  The initial communication and training of the process hazard analysis report and the entire PSM manual was perf

ormed on March 5-6, 2013.  Additional training and participation on the Thermo No. 1 Geothermal Power Plant Operations & Maintenance manual, hereafter referred to as the Operations & Maintenance Manual (O&M Manual) occurred April 1-5, 2013, by Ormat.  Upon the five (5) year renewal cycle and Revision 3 update of the entire PSM; the PHA, and all reference documents were again trained and communicated to all plant personnel on March 26, 2018.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(c) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

2) Process Safety Information

Thermo No. 1 compiled all the necessary process safety information before conducting the process hazard analysis required by the PSM standard.  The process safety information aids Thermo No. 1 and its employees in identifying and understanding the hazards posed by iso-pentane.  Process safety information includes information on the hazards of iso-pentane, the technology and on the equipment in the process.  The majority of this information is provided by experienced operators, the Operations & Maintenance Manual (O&M Manual), and construction turnover documentation.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(d) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

3) PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

Thermo No. 1 has performed an initial and a follow-up five (5) year process hazard analysis on the processes covered by the PSM standard.  The process hazard analysis considers the complexity of the process and appropriately identifies, evaluates and establishes controls for the hazards involved in the process.

Thermo No. 1 has determined and documented the priority for conducting the process hazard analyses based on the extent of the process hazards, number of potentially affected employees, age of the process, and operating history of the process.

The initial and five (5) year follow-up process hazard analysis was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and p

ted or found by the contractors work.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(h) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

7)   PRE-STARTUP REVIEW

Thermo No. 1 performed a pre-startup review for the process and any other modified facilities throughout the facilities operation life.  This review considers the process safety information prior to the introduction of isopentane to the process or placing a modified system into operation.

The pre-startup review confirms the following:

	Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;
	Safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
	A process hazard analysis has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup; and
	Training of each employee involved in the operating process has been completed.

The initial pre-startup review for the new process took place on April 8-9, 2013.  Follow-up pre-startup reviews must take place as required by the Management of Change process .

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(i) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

8)   MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Thermo No. 1 has established and implemented written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment.  All employees involved in maintaining the integrity of process equipment have been trained in the hazards and procedures applicable to the employees job tasks.

Manufacturers recommendations for inspection and testing has been implemented in operating procedures and performed at the required frequency.  Equipment deficiencies outside the acceptable limits defined by the process safety information have been and will be quickly corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Thermo No. 1 has assured that all equipment is fabricated and installed correctly.  They have also ensured that the appropriate maintenance materials, critical spare parts and equipment ar

e suitable for the process application for which they are used.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(j) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

9)  HOT WORK PERMIT

Thermo No. 1 has implemented a hot work permit procedure for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process.  The permit documents the fire prevention and protection requirements set forth in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) and was implemented prior to the beginning of hot work operations.  

Permits are kept on file until completion of the work and or Management of Change is complete.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(k) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

10)   MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Thermo No. 1 has established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures and changes to facilities that affect the covered process.  Employees and contractors whose jobs will be affected shall be informed and trained on the new process change.
If a proposed change involves modifications to procedures or practices found in the process safety information or operating procedures, such information shall be updated accordingly.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(l) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

11)   INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Thermo No. 1 will have a team investigate each incident, which could have resulted in a catastrophic release of iso-pentane from the process.  The investigations and corrective actions will be promptly initiated.  All relevant findings and resolutions shall be communicated to personnel whose job tasks are affected by the incident.  All investigation reports will be kept for at least five (5) years.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(m) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

12)   EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

Thermo No. 1 has developed and implemented an emer

gency action plan for the entire site in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38(a).  The plan includes procedures for handling small spills or releases.  Employees and contractors are trained on the applicable provisions of the emergency action plan (see sections 6 & 7).  

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(n) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

13)   COMPLIANCE AUDITS

Thermo No. 1 shall certify that they have evaluated compliance to the PSM standard and its provisions at least once every three (3) years.  The audit shall verify that the procedures and practices under PSM are being followed.  An audit report shall be generated indicating any deficiencies or findings.  Audit findings shall promptly be corrected and documented.  The two (2) most recent compliance audit reports and corrective actions must be kept on file. 

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(o) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.

14)   TRADE SECRETS

Thermo No. 1 shall make available to those persons responsible for compiling PSM information all process safety information, process hazard analyses, operating procedures, incident investigations, emergency planning/response and compliance audits without regard to the possible trade secret status of such information.  Thermo No. 1 does, however, retain the right to request that those persons requesting the information may need to enter into a confidentiality agreement not to disclose the information.  The plant manager or management staff shall make the determination on the need for such agreements on a case-by-case basis.

This section complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(p) of the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard.
